title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. Policies should encourage global technology standards, respect user security and privacy, promote innovation, and avoid restricting Internet service providers. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against a free, open Internet, such as mandating technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the use of Internet tools for unauthorized access. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against a free, open Internet, such as mandating technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the use of Internet tools for unauthorized access. This includes actions like blocking, filtering, and monitoring Internet communications in a discriminatory manner, as well as imposing market access requirements that hinder Internet-related goods and services from other countries. These actions threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating foreign governments' attempts to restrict or disrupt the free flow of information on the Internet. The curr_chunk highlights the negative impacts of restricting the free flow of information on the Internet, promoting national Internets, harming US workers and businesses, and risking the utility of the Internet for open communication and commerce. The curr_chunk introduces the establishment of a Task Force on the Global Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. The President selects a Chairperson from the Task Force members with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. Members are appointed by the President, President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, Senate majority and minority leaders, and House Speaker and minority leader. Appointments are for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force for renewable terms not to exceed 3 years includes various federal officials and agencies as determined by the President. Federal agencies can provide personnel or services to assist the Task Force upon request. The Task Force, composed of federal officials and agencies, is tasked with developing strategies to address government policies that hinder international trade in Internet-related goods and services, impede the free flow of information, or threaten the open nature of the Internet. The Task Force, composed of federal officials and agencies, is responsible for coordinating government efforts to address policies affecting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, information flow, and the open nature of the Internet. This includes consulting with civil society groups, coordinating federal departments, preparing reports and action plans, holding public hearings, and appointing a civilian Task Force member to lead and serve as a point of contact. The Task Force is responsible for coordinating government efforts related to international trade in Internet goods and services, information flow, and the open nature of the Internet. This includes preparing reports and action plans to be submitted to the President and Congress. The Task Force is mandated to submit reports and action plans to the President and Congress, identifying acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or restrict trade in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force is responsible for identifying acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or restrict trade in Internet-related goods and services. It also evaluates the impact of diverging technology standards on the United States' interests in global Internet communications and sets priorities for addressing these concerns with a strategy and action plan. The Task Force is responsible for identifying hindrances to fair market access in Internet-related trade, evaluating technology standard impacts, and setting priorities with a strategy and action plan. Reports and action plans may include a classified annex if deemed necessary, and public participation is encouraged through notices in the Federal Register. The Task Force is responsible for identifying hindrances to fair market access in Internet-related trade, evaluating technology standard impacts, and setting priorities with a strategy and action plan. This includes holding public hearings, establishing a website for public comments, consulting with relevant departments and agencies, sharing information with civil society groups, and considering input from various sources. The Task Force, responsible for fair market access in Internet-related trade, will publish reports and action plans in the Federal Register, omitting certain information transmitted to Congress. SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative will initiate investigations and take actions under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974 in response to priority concerns identified in annual reports and action plans. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will conduct reviews and investigations. SEC. 7. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. Antitrust laws include the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President assessing existing trade agreements related to Internet trade, technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user interests, recommending modifications or new agreements as needed. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President recommending modifications or new agreements to advance trade objectives. Congress believes future trade agreements should include specified goals. The report may include a classified annex if deemed necessary. Public participation will be sought through notices, hearings, and a Task Force website. The Task Force will establish a website for publishing information and receiving public comments. It will consult with relevant federal departments, civil society groups, and consider information from various sources for trade policy recommendations. The Task Force will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information from subsection (b), as required by the Act (19 U.S.C. 2412). The Task Force will coordinate training with various entities for foreign and domestic officials on standards-related best practices. Additionally, outside consultation will be sought. The Task Force will establish a process for receiving input from businesses, organizations, experts, and other parties regarding its functions.
